archiveTopNews.title: NSW coronavirus restrictions will be partially lifted to allow limited visiting
archiveTopNews.summary: People in New South Wales will soon be able to visit each other as the premier, Gladys Berejiklian, joins other state and territory governments in easing lockdown laws. In a press conference on Tuesday morning, Berejiklian said that since NSW infection rates remained low, two adults and their children would be able to travel to other homes to visit. A spokeswoman from the premier’s office said guests were allowed to stay overnight and there were no restrictions on distance.

archiveTopNews.title: Hundreds return to Sydney's famous Bondi Beach as coronavirus restrictions are eased
archiveTopNews.summary: Hundreds of surfers have returned to the water at Bondi for the first time since the beach was closed five weeks ago due to COVID-19 restrictions. People are now permitted to swim or surf at Bondi and Bronte, and surf only at Tamarama, between 7am and 5pm on weekdays. Access is via designated entry and exit points and the sand remains out of bounds for sunbathers.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia's aged care residents caught in standoff over visits during coronavirus
archiveTopNews.summary: Aged care residents and their families are caught in the crossfire of an escalating stand-off between the federal government and the sector over visiting rights during the Covid-19 pandemic. Ahead of a meeting with providers on Friday, the government suggested it was prepared to force homes to allow each resident two visitors a day, in line with official health guidelines, if operators did not ease their own rules. On Monday, a coalition of 1,000 aged care homes and their representatives roundly rejected the government’s request and disputed claims elevated by the prime minister that some homes were simply locking residents in their rooms.

archiveTopNews.title: More than two million Australians download COVIDSafe contact tracing app
archiveTopNews.summary: As of Monday 4pm, 1.89 million Australians had downloaded the COVID-19 tracer app, which aims to help health officials identify people who may have come into contact with someone with the disease. Chief medical officer Brendan Murphy called the result a positive start to bolstering the public health response against the coronavirus. The government has said 40 per cent - or some 10 million people - would be needed for contact-tracing to be most successful.

archiveTopNews.title: What is COVIDSafe, Australia's controversial new contact tracing app?
archiveTopNews.summary: On Sunday, the Federal Government launched a mobile phone app it hopes will improve the tracing of coronavirus cases and the people they come in contact with. The COVIDSafe app aims to identify people who may have come into contact with someone who has coronavirus so the user can give the information to health authorities. The COVIDSafe app is based on Singapore's Tracetogether software, which records the Bluetooth connections a phone makes with others, as part of what's being called a "Bluetooth handshake". But the launch came amid concerns about the technology and the data it would collect.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus stay-at-home restrictions to be eased in Queensland
archiveTopNews.summary: Queensland will relax some stay-at-home restrictions from midnight on Friday with less than 100 active COVID-19 cases across the state. Family picnics and weekend drives are back on the agenda for Queenslanders starting next weekend after just three COVID-19 cases were recorded overnight. Premier Annastacia Palaszcuk says the easing of restrictions would start at midnight on Friday and people would be limited to travel about 50km from their residence and “limited to members of your own household”.

archiveTopNews.title: WA to allow gatherings of up to 10 people as COVID-19 cases drop
archiveTopNews.summary: Western Australia will relax its coronavirus restrictions to allow up to 10 people to gather for non-work activities, as the state recorded another day of no new COVID-19 cases. Premier Mark McGowan said it was a "cautious relaxation" of restrictions, acknowledging it had been difficult for everyone, but especially the elderly, to not see family and friends during the pandemic. From Monday, non-contact recreational activities such as picnics in parks, fishing, boating, hiking and camping will be allowed but people must comply with travel restrictions. Ten people will be allowed at weddings and the 10-person limit remains for funerals.

archiveTopNews.title: Australians turn out for driveway dawn service to mark Anzac Day in time of coronavirus
archiveTopNews.summary: Thousands take part in a Covid-19-friendly but lonelier than usual commemoration of Gallipoli. The idea for the driveway dawn service came from two former Townsville defence force personnel, Warrant Officer Terry James and Brigadier Bill Sowry, who were discussing a Covid-19-friendly way to commemorate the day on social media. The plan quickly gained popularity and RSL branches and politicians across the country encouraged people to take part.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia ramps up coronavirus testing to include anyone with respiratory symptoms
archiveTopNews.summary: Following a national cabinet meeting on Friday, Chief Medical Officer Brendan Murphy announced all states and territories would expand their testing criteria to ensure any community transmission was being picked up. The meeting also discussed reports of aged care facilities refusing visitors and locking residents in their rooms. Prime Minister Scott Morrison said if facilities that had gone beyond baseline coronavirus requirements did not return to that level and allow each resident two visitors a day, his government would make it mandatory.

archiveTopNews.title: Scott Morrison says social distancing rules do not apply to school classrooms
archiveTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrison says the government's medical advice confirms social distancing requirements do not apply to classrooms, clearing the way for students to return to school.  While Australians have been told to keep 1.5 metres apart, or two arms' lengths, Mr Morrison said the Australian Health Protection Principal Committee (AHPPC) had determined students did not need to abide by that advice in the classroom.

archiveTopNews.title: Scott Morrison says JobSeeker payment will be cut after pandemic
archiveTopNews.summary: Scott Morrison has indicated that the JobSeeker allowance, formerly known as Newstart, will be reduced after the COVID-19 pandemic. So far, 587,686 people have signed up to the JobSeeker unemployment benefit during the pandemic. The payment is usually $40 a day but has been doubled for the next six months. However, Mr Morrison indicated he was not interested in extending this timeframe despite the fact many sacked employees will still be struggling to find work.

archiveTopNews.title: Anzac Appeal raises just 3% of target as street sales take a tumble
archiveTopNews.summary: Two days out from Anzac Day, RSL Victoria’s Anzac Appeal has raised less than 3 percent of this year's original goal. The appeal, an annual fundraiser to support war veterans and their families, normally gathers more than 90 per cent of its funds via street sales of badges in the weeks leading up to Anzac Day. With volunteers unable to sell badges this year due to social distancing restrictions, RSL Victoria has raised about $100,000 in online donations. Before the coronavirus pandemic RSL Victoria was hoping to collect $3.5 million this year – the 75th anniversary of the end of World War II – having raised between $3 million and $3.5 million in previous years.

archiveTopNews.title: WA $154m coronavirus relief package to help renters, landlords and the construction industry
archiveTopNews.summary: The West Australian Government has announced a relief package of $154 million to support tenants, landlords and the construction industry impacted by the coronavirus crisis. The package includes $30 million for grants of up to $2,000 to directly help residential tenants pay their rent if they are suffering hardship.

archiveTopNews.title: Coles, Woolies relax online restrictions
archiveTopNews.summary: Supermarket giants Woolworths and Coles have broadened their home delivery service for online customers, giving hope that life may be returning to normal amid ongoing coronavirus concerns. Coles this week reopened its home delivery, "click and collect", to all customers, after having previously limited orders for vulnerable and remote Australians because of the COVID-19 crisis. Woolworths will make "tens of thousands of extra weekly home delivery windows for online customers", WooliesX Managing Director Amanda Bardwell said in a statement on Wednesday.

archiveTopNews.title: Ban on elective surgeries, including IVF, to be gradually lifted from next week
archiveTopNews.summary: State and federal leaders agreed on Tuesday to gradually resume elective surgeries due to an increase in personal protective equipment and the slowdown of new coronavirus cases. Most elective surgeries were suspended last month to free up hospital capacity to deal with the coronavirus pandemic. Other procedures to restart after the Anzac Day long weekend include all children surgeries, joint replacements, eye procedures, endoscopy and colonoscopy.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia likely to experience largest economic downturn since the Great Depression
archiveTopNews.summary: Australia is likely to experience the greatest economic contraction since the Great Depression, according to the Reserve Bank of Australia, and has already lost 800,000 jobs and suffered a 6.7% reduction in take home pay, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. On Tuesday the RBA provided an economic update predicting a 10% decline in national output in the first half of 2020, a “staggeringly large” 20% reduction in hours worked and unemployment to hit 10% by June.

archiveTopNews.title: Privacy concerns persist over Australia's coronavirus tracing app
archiveTopNews.summary: Privacy concerns have been raised over Australia’s new coronavirus tracing app. The government services minister, Stuart Robert, has said that the data would remain “securely encrypted on your phone” unless you tested positive for Covid-19, in which case it would be accessed by state health authorities. However, digital experts have said that the federal government should formally make data collected from its Covid-19 tracing app exempt from use by law enforcement and “decentralise” the way it notifies users about potential contacts with the virus if it wants to allay privacy concerns.

archiveTopNews.title: ACT health authorities on high-alert for "second" wave of coronavirus cases
archiveTopNews.summary: ACT health authorities are on high alert for new COVID-19 cases to emerge once physical distancing restrictions are eased across the country. While chief health officer Kerryn Coleman says the territory may soon be in a position where there are no "active" cases of coronavirus with its borders, she insists that doesn't mean the ACT has successfully overcome the pandemic. Chief Minister Andrew Barr warned that any "early move out" of the restrictions would heighten the risk of exposing the ACT to a "second, third, fourth or fifth" wave of the pandemic.

archiveTopNews.title: Virgin Australia expected to go into administration
archiveTopNews.summary: Virgin Australia has reportedly filed for voluntary administration after the struggling airline asked the government for a $1.4 billion bail-out. The jobs of 16,000 employees are on the line, and board members are currently having crisis talks to decide the fate of the carrier. Virgin is carrying about $5b in debt and its domestic and international business has been hit due to the impact of the coronavirus.

archiveTopNews.title: Aeromedical services like RFDS get $52.8m boost for coronavirus response
archiveTopNews.summary: A federal funding boost to the Royal Flying Doctor Service (RFDS) and other aeromedical services will see the capacity for rural and remote medical evacuations increase by 50 per cent. The services, which also include CareFlight and LifeFlight, will share in $52.8 million to evacuate COVID-19 patients to larger medical centres and also fly in medical workers and equipment to staff respiratory clinics.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia has a 'sustained and genuine' flattening of the coronavirus curve, Greg Hunt says
archiveTopNews.summary: Health Minister Greg Hunt says Australia has "a sustained and genuine flattening of the curve" with COVID-19 infection rate increases below one per cent a day for the past seven days. Australia's infection rate of COVID-19 is flattening, with the rate of new cases falling below one per cent and just 53 in the past 24 hours.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus to cripple Cairns for years, tourism experts say
archiveTopNews.summary: Tourism authorities fear it could take years for Far North Queensland's tourism-driven economy to recover from the coronavirus pandemic. Tourism Tropical North Queensland estimates the region will have lost $500 million in visitor spending by the end of April, with the total impact on the region expected to be $2.5 billion in lost visitor expenditure. More than 5,000 workers have been stood down so far, with 11,000 more people expected to be out of work by the end of the year.

archiveTopNews.title: A 'mammoth effort' to bring Australians home from overseas during coronavirus crisis, with more to return this week
archiveTopNews.summary: Australia's Foreign Minister Marise Payne says the federal government continues to work with the Qantas, Virgin Australia and foreign airlines to bring home Australians stranded in various parts of the world because of the coronavirus pandemic. She said about 300,000 people have returned to Australia since March 13, a significant number of those from more than 50 cruise ships. Currently there are about 11,000 Australians scattered around the world - though many of them are long-term residents of the countries in which they're located.

archiveTopNews.title: Falling power use due to coronavirus risks system overload and blackouts, experts warn
archiveTopNews.summary: Falling demand for electricity caused by the economic fallout from the COVID-19 pandemic could leave Western Australia's main electricity system at risk of a solar power overload within months, experts have warned. This may overwhelm the grid, meaning intervention and higher prices.

archiveTopNews.title: People with disability to be protected under new plan during Australia's coronavirus crisis
archiveTopNews.summary: More than four million Australians with disability in Australia have been assured of their safety during the coronavirus pandemic through their reduced exposure to the virus, while maintaining essential services. The national cabinet - made up of the prime minister, premiers and chief ministers - when it last met on Thursday agreed on a management and operational plan for people with disability during the crisis.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus mobile tracking app may be mandatory if not enough people sign up, Scott Morrison says
archiveTopNews.summary: Mobile phone tracking software could be compulsory if not enough Australians voluntarily download the application to help in coronavirus case tracing. Prime Minister Scott Morrison said at least 40 percent of the population needs to use the app to make it effective. Better contact tracing is one of three main benchmarks the government wants to meet before strict restrictions can be lifted. Notably, Mr Morrison says the app won't be used by police as evidence to prosecute people for breaching social distancing requirements.

archiveTopNews.title: Internet costs cut for low-income Australian families, small businesses during coronavirus pandemic
archiveTopNews.summary: Internet providers will have help ensuring financially-stricken families and businesses stay connected from a $150 million National Broadband Network relief fund. The internet wholesaler wants to ensure families with school children who do not have NBN access, and small and medium-sized businesses, can remain online during and after the coronavirus pandemic. NBN will waive its $37 monthly charge to internet providers between April and September to allow the industry to devise more affordable access for families.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia's coronavirus restrictions will remain until these three things are established
archiveTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrison has announced that Australians will have to live with coronavirus restrictions for at least another four weeks. He outlined three things the Government wants to see before parts of the country can start to look normal again. These three things are: a broader testing regime, better contact tracing, and being confident in containing outbreaks.

archiveTopNews.title: 'Game changer': Coronavirus testing to be fast-tracked in remote Indigenous communities
archiveTopNews.summary: 83 coronavirus testing sites are set to be set up across remote Indigenous communities to detect the virus more rapidly. Some remote areas have been waiting up to 10 days for results but the new $3.3 million project, part of the wider $2.4 billion COVID-19 National Health Plan, aims to cut waiting times to 45 minutes.

archiveTopNews.title: COVID-19 vaccine testing to begin in Australia in coming weeks
archiveTopNews.summary: Phase one testing for a COVID-19 vaccine is set to begin in Australia, in only the third such trial in the world. Australian clinical trials specialist Nucleus Network will partner with US-based biotechnology company Novavax to begin the testing of the NVX-CoV2373 vaccine in the coming weeks. It will be the first COVID-19 vaccine to be tested outside the US. The phase one trial is expected to begin in mid-May, with preliminary results by July.

archiveTopNews.title: Australian government plans to bring in mobile phone app to track people with coronavirus
archiveTopNews.summary: Australia soon will adopt a sophisticated mobile phone app that tracks coronavirus victims and the people they come in contact with. The federal government wants to introduce the app, now being used in Singapore, within a fortnight and will outline the plan to premiers during the next meeting of the national cabinet on Thursday. It will be part of a broader strategy to point to an exit from the tough Covid-19 restrictions which have shut businesses and confined millions to their homes.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus Australia: World Health Organisation lists criteria for reducing restrictions
archiveTopNews.summary: The World Health Organisation (WHO) has released new criteria countries must adhere to before even considering lifting coronavirus restrictions. Six key factors that must be followed were announced on Tuesday morning. It follows countries easing their restrictions and seeing a second wave of outbreaks. The six WHO guidelines are: Transmission of the virus is controlled; Health systems can detect every case; Outbreak risks are minimised; Preventative measures are in place; Importation risks can be managed; and Communities are educated and empowered to adjust to the “new norm”.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia will need to raise GST to pay coronavirus debt, tax expert says
archiveTopNews.summary: Tax reform including a GST increase and higher land tax will be needed to avoid the debt burden of the $214bn Covid-19 economic response falling on young people, an academic tax expert has warned.

archiveTopNews.title: School closures and recommencement dates across Australia
archiveTopNews.summary: As the Easter holidays come to a close for some states, students and parents are now turning their minds to how Term 2 will look at their schools. Each state and territory is slightly different across Australia. This article outlines the current plan from each State Government going into Term 2.

archiveTopNews.title: The eligibility requirements you must meet to be tested for COVID-19 in each state
archiveTopNews.summary: With eligibility requirements for testing of COVID-19 changing all the time and with every state requiring different eligibility in order to be tested, it can be difficult to keep track. Here is a state-by-state break down of latest eligibility guidelines for each state and territory.

archiveTopNews.title: Queensland schools to open for term two for vulnerable students and children of essential workers amid coronavirus
archiveTopNews.summary: Queensland schools will open for term two for vulnerable students and the children of essential workers, Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk says. Other students will be taught from home via remote learning online for at least the first five weeks of the term. These rules would be in place until May 22 and reviewed on May 15.

archiveTopNews.title: NSW Government to announce $440 million coronavirus rental assistance with moratorium on forced evictions
archiveTopNews.summary: The New South Wales State Government has announced $440 million in relief for renters and landlords affected by Government-enforced COVID-19 restrictions. They are allocating $220 million to residential renters and landlords and a further $220 million towards shops, gyms, hairdressers and businesses affected by COVID-19.

archiveTopNews.title: Victorian state of emergency extended for another month as new coronavirus cases decline
archiveTopNews.summary: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews announced the state of emergency imposed in his state will be extended by four weeks to midnight on May 11

archiveTopNews.title: Higher education institutions to offer cut-price courses after coronavirus pandemic
archiveTopNews.summary: The federal government has also announced that higher education institutions will be offering cut price courses starting in May to fill skill shortages to assist the economic rebound once the pandemic has run its course. The online courses will run for six months in what are deemed to be "areas of national priority", such as in nursing, teaching, counselling, IT and science.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus ‘mercy’ flight with COVID-19 positive passengers lands in Melbourne
archiveTopNews.summary: A ‘mercy flight’ carrying 80 coronavirus-infected Australians has touched down in Melbourne. Emergency services were on standby at Tullamarine airport to meet the plane, which was carrying 112 passengers in total. Those passengers are among 1200 Australian nationals being flown home from overseas by the Commonwealth this weekend, with flights from India and Peru landing on Friday and Saturday.

archiveTopNews.title: Clinical trial to test if tuberculosis vaccine can be used to boost immunity against COVID-19
archiveTopNews.summary: Clinical trial for 500 frontline health workers in South Australia will test if the BCG vaccine normally used to combat tuberculosis, can boost immunity against COVID-19.

archiveTopNews.title: Antibody tests for the novel coronavirus could be available within 'a week or so'
archiveTopNews.summary: Antibody tests that would verify whether a person recently had the novel coronavirus could be available within a week, according to the America's top infectious disease expert. Having antibodies to the coronavirus could mean someone is protected from getting re-infected, making such tests important for medical workers and others on the frontlines fighting the pandemic.

archiveTopNews.title: 'Stop looking for loopholes': What are the new COVID-19 social rules?
archiveTopNews.summary: Government urges people to stop looking for loopholes over the Easter weekend, so as not to undo all of the hard work that has been done to stop the spread of COVID-19. This article covers questions such as whether you can have people over, whether you can go away at Easter and whether you can babysit, state-by-state.

archiveTopNews.link: Coronavirus vaccine research enters new phase as University of Queensland researchers start testing it on the live COVID-19 virus
archiveTopNews.title: Aussie households to be given access to COVID-19 financial stress for bills
archiveTopNews.summary: Australian households struggling with financial stress brought on by the coronavirus pandemic will soon have access to hardship provisions for their energy and water bills. Prime Minister Scott Morrison said the new measures would be in line with those across the energy and telecommunications sectors to scale-up hardship support provided by those industries.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus vaccine research enters new phase as University of Queensland researchers start testing it on the live COVID-19 virus
archiveTopNews.summary: The effectiveness of a University of Queensland (UQ) vaccine against the coronavirus is about to be tested in a biosecurity facility in the Netherlands. The vaccine will be used on live coronavirus for the first time to determine how effectively it induces protection against infection. UQ's vaccine program co-leader Dr Keith Chappell says the trial will establish a critical package of data ahead of human clinical trials later this year.Clinical studies will be conducted by Viroclinics Xplore, which offers myriad pre-clinical tests including toxicology of drugs, antibodies, and antivirals targeting viral infectious diseases.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus crisis: Prime Minister Scott Morrison urges Australians to stay at home in Easter message
archiveTopNews.summary: Scott Morrison has used his annual Easter message to urge Australians to stay home, saying the country “cannot undo the tremendous progress” it has made towards flattening the curve of coronavirus cases. He states that immediate - but not extended - family may spend their Easter together, and that Australians will not be able to attend Easter services.

archiveTopNews.title: Essential fruit and veg pickers 'homeless' due to coronavirus, meaning crops may be left to rot
archiveTopNews.summary: The fruit and vegetable industry has warned that crops may be left to rot in fields because of a major shortage of accommodation for backpackers who pick the produce. These young travellers say they are camping illegally and sleeping in their cars because many hostels and caravan parks are closed.

archiveTopNews.title: Australia's small medical practices on brink of collapse amid coronavirus
archiveTopNews.summary: Smaller doctor-owned general practices are on the brink of financial collapse due to revenue losses from Covid-19, prompting fears more patients will be unnecessarily pushed into an already overstretched hospital system. Peak medical bodies and the health minster, Greg Hunt, on Thursday urged Australians to continue seeing their GPs, saying Covid-19 should not mean people “ignore the doctor” or their ordinary health needs.

archiveTopNews.title: No time to relax in costly virus fight: PM
archiveTopNews.summary: Australia's death toll from the coronavirus has hit 50 as political leaders warn now is not the time to ease the measures that are preventing much higher fatality rates. The daily increase in new cases has dropped to about three per cent, but health experts are concerned COVID-19 could be widely transmitted among unwitting community members. However, Health Minister Greg Hunt warned abandoning social distancing rules over the long weekend would undo everything done to curtail the crisis.

archiveTopNews.title: Are you immune to coronavirus after recovering? This test might be able to tell you
archiveTopNews.summary: Australian researchers are working on a test they say will be able to predict the severity of symptoms in COVID-19 patients, telling them how hard the virus will hit them after they contract it and what their immunity will be when they recover.

archiveTopNews.title: Scott Morrison's press conference: Coronavirus modelling, rental tenancies and what you shouldn't do this Easter
archiveTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrison and Chief Medical Officer Brendan Murphy addressed the nation this afternoon with some more important updates about the COVID-19 crisis. Topics included progress on flattening the curve, Easter weekend, the modelling that was released today, rental issues, asymptomatic carriers, schools, and more.

archiveTopNews.title: ATO’s coronavirus measures: What you can claim on your tax return if you’re working from home
archiveTopNews.summary: With COVID-19 restrictions forcing more Australians than ever to work from home, come tax time, people are going to be able to claim deductions on anything they use to do their job - such as office furniture, computers, tablets, phone and internet bills. For running expenses like heating, cooling and lighting, the Australian Tax Office is offering a special COVID-19 flat rate tax deduction of 80 cents an hour that you can claim instead of having to calculate the costs manually.

archiveTopNews.title: Drop in daily testing coronavirus rates possible sign of Australia 'flattening the curve'
archiveTopNews.summary: A major drop in the number of people being tested daily for COVID-19 is not a result of a lack of testing kits, but of a drop in the number of people presenting with symptoms, Deputy Chief Medical officer Professor Michael Kidd said. Last month, more than 4000 tests were being conducted daily however that number has fallen to closer to 2700 a day. Professor Kidd told Today this was more likely a result of Australia beginning to flatten the curve.

archiveTopNews.title: Lack of PPE forces Aboriginal health groups to stop testing for coronavirus
archiveTopNews.summary: A number of Aboriginal health groups in Victoria have been forced to cease COVID-19 testing and consider shutting their doors due to a lack of personal protective equipment. Some clinics had just two weeks of personal protective equipment left with no immediate prospect of re-supply, creating a situation they described as “catastrophic”.The NSW Government has now written to the Commonwealth asking for the urgent release of supplies to the state’s Aboriginal medical services and for direct access to the Government’s national medical stockpile.

archiveTopNews.title: Australian doctors design and make life-saving equipment needed for coronavirus pandemic
archiveTopNews.summary: Australian doctors who are worried the system will not be able to provide them with the equipment they need to protect themselves and their patients during the COVID-19 pandemic are looking at ways to design and produce their own. A large centralised group involving Victorian university staff, clinicians and manufacturers has been working tirelessly to develop suitable products and to co-ordinate the supply and demand of these essential items.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus Australia: Free hotel stay for Victoria’s healthcare workers on the frontline
archiveTopNews.summary: Victoria’s frontline health workers will have free hotel stays if they need to self-isolate during the coronavirus crises, as the state recorded 20 new cases overnight. Premier Daniel Andrews said on Sunday the government will provide $20 million to buy a range of hotel rooms for up to 8000 frontline workers.

archiveTopNews.title: Chief Medical Officer Brendan Murphy 'increasingly confident' Australia can stay on top of coronavirus
archiveTopNews.summary: Chief Medical Officer Brendan Murphy says Australia is succeeding at flattening the curve and that he is increasingly confident Australia will avoid the kind of devastation the coronavirus has caused in countries like Italy and the United States. However, his biggest concern remains community transmission, which accounts for 10 per cent of cases in Australia.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus Australia: Visa changes open the door for foreign workers to extend their stay
archiveTopNews.summary: A series of visa changes have been made which means working holidaymakers who are working in critical sectors will be exempt from the six-month work limitation with one employer and eligible for a further visa to keep working if their current visa is due to expire in the next six months. Additionally, temporary visa holders who have already worked in Australia will also have access to their superannuation and New Zealanders who arrived in Australia before February 26, 2001, will gain access to welfare payments and JobKeeper.

archiveTopNews.title: Coles and Woolworths introduce coronavirus measures to limit number of customers inside stores
archiveTopNews.summary: Coles and Woolworths are dramatically escalating their social distancing policies by introducing a limit on the number of customers inside stores. From Monday 6th of April, until the foreseeable future, shoppers will be forced to wait in cordoned off queues outside until people inside leave. The number of customers allowed inside varies depending on the size of the store itself.

archiveTopNews.title: Scott Morrison gave a rundown of the latest coronavirus measures after today's National Cabinet meeting. Here's what he said.
archiveTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrison and Chief Medical Officer Brendan Murphy gave an update after today's National Cabinet meeting. They discussed big changes for how we live our lives, with business closures, social distancing rules, Easter services, commercial leases, the fate of seasonal workers and international students, and more.

archiveTopNews.title: Free childcare: what do the Australian government's coronavirus changes mean for my family?
archiveTopNews.summary: The federal government says it will make Australian childcare services free during the coronavirus crisis, with priority given to parents who need to continue working. It is also promoting its plan as a way to help childcare centres remain open and viable through the crisis.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus Australia update: CSIRO tests potential COVID-19 vaccines
archiveTopNews.summary: CSIRO scientists are performing the first stage of testing for two vaccine candidates at the agency’s high-containment biosecurity facility in Geelong. The pre-clinical trials, which are expected to take three months, will use animal subjects to test whether the potential vaccines from the University of Oxford and Inovio Pharmaceuticals are safe and effective.

archiveTopNews.title: Australian coronavirus testing hits world-leading levels above 1 per cent of population, Scott Morison says
archiveTopNews.summary: More than 260,000 coronavirus tests have been carried out across the country as Australia continues to respond to the spread of the deadly pandemic. Those testing levels equate to more than 1 per cent of the population, which Prime Minister Scott Morrison said was a world-leading rate. By 4:00pm on Thursday, Australia had conducted 268,554 coronavirus tests. Nationally, there are more than 5,100 confirmed cases of the coronavirus, and the death toll has risen to 24.

archiveTopNews.title: Australian employees entitled to 'pandemic leave' as part of sweeping industrial relations changes caused by coronavirus
archiveTopNews.summary: Eligible Australian employees are now entitled to two weeks' "pandemic leave" if they need to self-isolate during the coronavirus pandemic as part of sweeping industrial relations changes announced today. The Minister for Industrial Relations, Christian Porter, has announced changes to 103 of Australia's 121 existing employee awards.

archiveTopNews.title: Get flu vaccinations earlier than usual because of coronavirus, GPs urge Australians
archiveTopNews.summary: Australians are being urged to get their flu vaccination as soon as possible to reduce strain on the health system caused by COVID-19. The flu vaccine won't combat COVID-19, but it will help to reduce the severity and spread of seasonal influenza, which can lower a person's immunity and make them susceptible to other illnesses. Flu vaccines are available from your local GP - though be sure to call ahead to check they’re in stock.

archiveTopNews.title: Retired nurses, doctors, pharmacists to be re-instated to help fight coronavirus
archiveTopNews.summary: More than 40,000 former doctors, nurses, midwives and pharmacists are being urged to re-join the medical workforce, to bolster the front line in Australia's fight against coronavirus. The former medical professionals would be added to the general register for a year, under a pandemic sub-register. To ensure public safety, practitioners who have been struck off the register will not be eligible to take part.

archiveTopNews.title: Federal Government offers $130b in coronavirus wage subsidies for businesses to pay workers
archiveTopNews.summary: The Government expects up to 6 million people will access a $1,500 fortnightly wage subsidy. The so-called JobKeeper payment is designed to keep people in work. The Government will also lift the means-testing threshold for the partners of JobSeeker recipients.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus update Australia: Scott Morrison announces strictest gathering measures yet
archiveTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrison has announced the strictest gathering recommendations to date - that no more than two people gather in public spaces at any given time. This move also spells the closure for public areas, such as playgrounds, outdoor gyms and skate parks, though restrictions on weddings and funerals will stay the same.

archiveTopNews.title: Federal Government launches Coronavirus Australia app and WhatsApp feature
archiveTopNews.summary: The Coronavirus Australia app allows users to navigate the latest advice and information about coronavirus. In addition to the new features, the Federal Government also detailed its $1.1 billion healthcare package.

archiveTopNews.title: Health Minister Greg Hunt says there are early signs that Australia is flattening the curve, even though coronavirus cases are still on the rise.
archiveTopNews.summary: The Federal Government said the rate of increase of cases was about 25-30 per cent a day last week, which has fallen to about 13-15 per cent this weekend. However, they warn that Australians must continue to follow social distancing and self-isolation guidelines.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus patients’ average age only 48 as Australian tally soars beyond 3,400
archiveTopNews.summary: There are now 3,400 cases of the virus in Australia, a vast majority of which have been diagnosed in New South Wales and Victoria. The median age of Australians diagnosed with novel coronavirus has been revealed to be 48 years old. However, the average age of fatalities is 77.

archiveTopNews.title: Global economy is in recession: IMF head
archiveTopNews.summary: The head of the International Monetary Fund says it is clear that the global economy has now entered a recession that could be as bad or worse than the 2009 downturn. IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva forecasted a recovery in 2021, but she said this would only occur if countries succeed in containing the coronavirus and limiting the economic damage.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus in Australia: Army called in to help enforce strict new quarantine rules
archiveTopNews.summary: The Australian Army will be deployed across all states and territories, stepping in to assist governments with new measures. The ADF will assist in both monitoring Friday’s regulations for returned overseas travellers and ensuring compliance checks with those in self-isolation at their homes. However, the prime minister says the army will not have the power to prosecute or arrest.

archiveTopNews.title: No national decision on school closures over coronavirus, PM says states must decide
archiveTopNews.summary: Prime Minister Scott Morrison has announced that the decision on whether to close schools before the end of term will be up to each state premier. He also stated that over the next few weeks, the schools themselves will be preparing, on a national basis, to get some consistency about when schools will reopen on the other side of school holidays.

archiveTopNews.title: International travellers returning to Australia to be sent to quarantine facilities for two weeks
archiveTopNews.summary: Australians returning from international travel will be quarantined in hotels and other accommodation facilities for two weeks before being allowed to go home, under new measures to control the spread of coronavirus. The measure will affect all international travellers returning after midnight on Saturday 28th of March.

archiveTopNews.title: Jobless queues to grow amid virus shutdown
archiveTopNews.summary: Thousands of people have been queuing at Centrelink offices as tighter restrictions on businesses, community facilities and public spaces came into effect, causing many people to lose their jobs. Economists predict 814,000 Australians will be added to dole queues before the end of June. Centrelink is rapidly recruiting an extra 5000 staff to deal with the influx of demand.

archiveTopNews.title: Coronavirus jobs fallout: at least 35,000 workers stood down in three days as businesses reel
archiveTopNews.summary: At least 35,000 people have been put out of work in just three days by casinos, airlines, retailers and other businesses that have stood down their workers in response to the coronavirus crisis. Westpac’s chief economist, Bill Evans, said the coronavirus crisis would cost 814,000 jobs by June, more than doubling the unemployment rate to 11.1%.
